abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Pathogenic germline <jats:italic>DICER1</jats:italic> variants are associated with pleuropulmonary blastoma, multinodular goiter, embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma and other tumour types, while mosaic missense <jats:italic>DICER1</jats:italic> variants in the RNase IIIb domain are linked to cause GLOW (global developmental delay, lung cysts, overgrowth, and Wilms’ tumor) syndrome. Here, we report four families with germline <jats:italic>DICER1</jats:italic> pathogenic variants in which one member in each family had a more complex phenotype, including skeletal findings, facial dysmorphism and developmental abnormalities. The developmental features occur with a variable expressivity and incomplete penetrance as also described for the neoplastic and dysplastic lesions associated with <jats:italic>DICER1</jats:italic> variants. Whole exome sequencing (WES) was performed on all four cases and revealed no further pathogenic or likely pathogenic dominant, homozygous or compound heterozygous variants in three of them. Notably, a frameshift variant in <jats:italic>ARID1B</jats:italic> was detected in one patient explaining part of her phenotype. This series of patients shows that pathogenic <jats:italic>DICER1</jats:italic> variants may be associated with a broader phenotypic spectrum than initially assumed, including predisposition to different tumours, skeletal findings, dysmorphism and developmental abnormalities, but genetic work up in syndromic patients should be comprehensive in order not to miss additional underlying /modifying causes.</jats:p>

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: This research study was conducted retrospectively from data obtained for clinical purposes. Approval was obtained from the ethics committee of the Uniklinik RWTH Aachen (EK 328/20).

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: Written informed consent was obtained from patients / minor(s)' legal guardian for the publication of any potentially identifiable images included in this article.
